utterances: Well, there wasn't a - this looks like a...
Unidentified Woman #1: No, no, no. This is not a road.
This was never a road.
That's the existing road.
Unidentified Woman #3: This is brand new road.
The neighbors insisted the developer should have gotten a permit from the federal government.
Wetlands are protected under the Federal Clean Water Act, they argued, and only the U.S.
Army Corps of Engineers can issue permits to fill them.
Specifically, they said the developers should have gotten permission from a corps official named Michael O'Keefe before construction started.
Finally, Adam Johnson, the developer's representative threw up his hands and said fine.
Will that make - would that satisfy everyone, if Michael O'Keefe came hear and said everything's great?
Unidentified Woman #4: Just like the DNR and county have?
Would that satisfy this group of people?
Unidentified Man #1: That would satisfy me.
(Soundbite of hands clapping)
We'll have him out here.
Two weeks later, Michael O'Keefe did come out to North Crab Lake, and he decided the neighbors were right about the road.
Mr.
MICHAEL O'KEEFE (Army Corps of Engineers): It's going to end up sliding downward into the adjacent wetland areas.
Then it would just cover over the vegetation that's there.
So basically, what you end up doing is you end up impacting or eliminating that wetland system.
And that's a problem, he says, because the wetland keeps North Crab Lake clean and healthy.
O'Keefe says what happened at North Crab Lake is becoming more common.
Mr.

O'KEEFE: It just seems to be that activities, or construction activities that could have potentially impact wetland systems in my area here in northern Wisconsin - there seems to be less reporting of that.
It's frustrating.
It's real frustrating that - to see that go on.
Permitting officials pin part of the blame on growing confusion over which wetlands the Clean Water Act actually protects.
For decades, the corps said the act covered practically any wetland, even a small isolated one.
If a bird can stop at a wetland, well then the corps could assert jurisdiction over it.
Duane Desiderio is vice president of the National Association of Homebuilders.
He says developers and others went to court to challenge that interpretation.
The Supreme Court has issued two rulings.
David Bookbinder, a senior attorney at the Sierra Club, says the rulings have narrowed the law's reach.
Before, it was clear-cut -virtually everything fell under the Clear Water Act jurisdiction.
Now the court is going to have to prove that a wetland falls under the Clean Water Act, and that is a very, very resource-intensive effort.
And the court does not have those resources.
Environmentalists say the decisions have also had a chilling effect on the Environmental Protection Agency, which issues fines for wetlands violations.
Eric Schaeffer - head of the EPA's Enforcement Office in both the Clinton and Bush administrations - he now he heads up a group called the Environmental Integrity Project.
In the late '90s, we were bringing about 55 enforcement actions a year - 55 to 60.
That's down to 35 to 40 in a typical year in the Bush administration.
He says for the law to work, it has to be clear and there have to be penalties for breaking it.
MR.
SCHAEFFER: We have a situation now where the law itself has shrunk because of these court decisions and where enforcement is really sporadic.

So what you see on paper and what you may take for granted, which is that, you know, wetlands are - we recognize that they're valuable and they're protected under the law and you can't willy-nilly just fill them.
That's really no longer true.
In Wisconsin, Michael O'Keefe of the Army Corps of Engineers says he's doing the best he can under the circumstances.
At North Crab Lake, for instance, he cited the developer for violating the Clean Water Act.
He asked him to voluntarily regrade the road and haul out some of the fill.
Mr.
O'KEEFE: My first effort is to try to protect the wetland system.
I know that the wetland system's been impacted, but my first course of action is to get restoration.
And mainly it's through voluntary restoration.
The developer, Rick Ernst(ph), now admits he made a mistake and says he's cooperating.
I was probably at fault because we did disturb part of a wetland.
We did need a permit to do that, which they are now granting us after the fact.
Ernst will have to pay $1,000 for his permit, twice the usual cost, but he won't have to regrade the road.
Instead, the developer will just dig out some of the mud that's coating parts of the wetland and try to stabilize steep slopes with mats, topsoil and vegetation.
Michael O'Keefe of the Army Corps says it made sense to compromise rather than go to court.
Mr.

O'KEEFE: Once you get into enforcement, there's a lot of burden of proof on the federal agency to prove that a wetland system was impacted and what level of impact that was and then pursue that through legal channels.
Legal action could take years, he says.
And by then, the road would already be in the lake.
And local permitting experts say the wetland next to North Crab Lake will get more protection than most.
They estimate that only one in ten builders in northern Wisconsin who illegally fill wetlands ever gets caught.
Kathleen Schalch, NPR News.
Music industry trade groups and music downloading sites, like Apple's iTunes, Napster, and eMusic, earned more than $5 million last year.
The music on these digital shelves comes from the major record labels and from what are called aggregators; these are middlemen who represent small and independent labels.
As NPR's Felix Contreras explains, there is one aggregator who's added a successful twist to the business.
The recent demise of music retail giant Tower Records has been seen by many as a symbolic end of the brick and mortar record store.
Mitch Koulouris was ready for that shift.
He worked as a manager for Tower during the retailer's heyday from the late 1970s through 1990.
Five years ago, he says he saw the writing on the wall.
Digital music distribution was the wave of the future, so he came up with a plan to carve out a bit of the digital landscape for his company, Digital Music Group, Inc., or DMGI.
The plan was based on his experience at Tower Records.

Tower was known for being able to go into their stores, buy a hit record of the day - whether it was Bon Jovi or Madonna, or whatever it was - as well as to go to the back of the store and maybe hit the classical section, and the jazz section, and flip through, you know, any number of Oscar Peterson records.
So they really took pride in caring deep catalogue along with the hits.
As far as the digital music opportunity, it seemed clear that this was going to be the best way to be able to exploit catalogue of every kind.
Koulouris figured you could do the same in the digital world by selling less of more.
Every track in our catalogue - we have over 200,000-plus tracks in our catalogue - sells at least five or six times a month.
So - on average.
So when you multiply that by hundreds of thousands of tracks, the economics become, you know, pretty darn compelling pretty quickly.
Here's an example.
(Soundbite of Sugar Sugar by The Archies)
(Singing) Honey, honey.
You are myâ€¦
In 1969, Sugar Sugar was the number one hit for the animated television characters, The Archies.
DMGI paid for the digital rights for the song in 2004, and it is now downloaded thousands of times per month.
It feels like I've got a second life.
Ron Dante is getting royalty checks from online sales of the song, as the voice of the cartoon lead singer.
Eventually, Dante left The Archies and went to work for Barry Manilow, producing all of the singer's mega hits of the 1980s.
From his perspective as a successful music industry veteran, Dante says what happened with Sugar Sugar shows online sales don't need the big promotional push from record labels and radio.
The people generate the downloads, not the big music companies.
And they're not spoon-fed what to buy this week.
They have their tastes, and they go after it, and they find it on the net.
Now regarding the EU Constitution itself, we were told that all 25 members of the European Union had to ratify this Constitution in order for it to take effect.
France has now said no. The Netherlands votes later this week and may well vote no. Does this mean that the Constitution is dead?
Well, that's right.
Brussels is still officially saying `No, we're going to go through the ratification process and see who says yes.
But what people are saying is they were so taken aback by the sudden rise of the French `no' that there is really--there has been no other plan.

So they're saying that they're going forward, but let's face it, if Holland says no tomorrow, that's two EU founders rejecting it and not only will it lose momentum, but it's pretty much going to be dead.
They're saying that, you know, they're going to have to go back to the drawing board and ask `What do Europeans really want from a European Union?'
They might have to renegotiate a Constitution from scratch or just give up?
They're saying that they do want to go through and see who is going to approve it.
They may have to change their whole idea of what a union would mean to people.
What's the mood that you sense as you walk around the streets of Paris today?
